The entire territory was surrounded by a high but transparent fence, which, to match the surrounding parks and courtyards of medical in-stitutions, consisted of a steel peaks palisade. The gates were pad-locked, except for one, behind which, in the depths of the yard, sat a fat man in a characteristic sleeveless underwear shirt and an absent-minded expression on his face. In this compartment of the yard, viewed from the street, there were several modest (according to Mos-cow center norms, where every third car is a black Mercedes, and every fifth - Land Rover of some color) cars. Perhaps the man’s job was to keep an eye on those vehicles, or, maybe, he was there to keep potential squatters out. One way or another, he did not sit there all the time, absenting himself for his own needs, so, having seized the right moment, I “leaked” through the gate and further - into the backyard, where the additional design features appeared before me in all the details: such as balconies running along the facade, that connected several residential units like cabins on the middle deck of a passenger steamer, and windows built into the building’s corners.

After a binge hour of drawing my favorite subjects, I finally looked around and found behind and around me many cars of the same ordi-nary kind. They were parked right on the grassy rubble courtyard, all of them having parking permit tags hanging on the rear-view mirrors. Their number exceeded expectations with the obvious emptiness of the concrete ruins, but it could well have matched the needs of the residents of the erected more recently, ten-story building, which was located at the far edge of the surrounded by a common fence territory, Probably, that building belonged to the same institution. In addition, I noticed a couple of the owners who might have thought that my pres-ence and, most importantly, behavior (writes and draws something in a notebook) was a violation of the established order. Thus, they could have come up with who knows what conclusions not in my favor. One way or another, it was necessary to think about an orderly retreat. As I wasn’t looking forward to explaining myself to the fat man in the T-shirt who in the meantime returned to his post, I cowardly slipped away through the bushes to the exit that opened from the side of the new building in order to let the next legitimate client into the parking lot. Once again on the street, I rushed away.  In fact, there was noth-ing else for me to do there, except climbing inside one of the concrete wrecks and run through endless corridors with the possible risk of falling through or hanging on a protruding steel rebar. But it hadn’t come to that, then, now, and ever... 

The name Constructivism appeared several years earlier than the cor-responding construction method. This seems to have been one of the "-isms" coined to denote a new trend in visual arts in response to the discovery by Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso of the Cubist style in France. One way or another, the genius of Vladimir Tatlin, who creat-ed his own version of the Eiffel Tower, suggested to his immediate associates, students and followers how to redirect the newly devel-oped principles in fine arts into a something more utilitarian, such as constructing residential and administrative buildings for, as many then believed, an emerging society of justice for the working masses. Thanks to the efforts of Moisey Ginzburg, the three Vesnin brothers and other pioneers, Constructivism in architecture arose as a material expression of the proclaimed ideals of the new world and, to some extent, enjoyed the support of those who came to power in 1917. 

As is often the case, the style under discussion eludes precise defini-tions and must be described in comparative terms. Directed, accord-ing to its creators, to reduce the cost of construction via rational archi-tecture, it sought to get as far as possible from the canons of the bour-geoisie, embodied in the Art Nouveau and Modern styles, which fas-cinated the cultural layer of the newly rich - merchants and industrial-ists of the early 20th century. Mosaics, stained-glass, window frames resembling lotus flowers, and fanciful balconies were replaced with concrete buildings and several new (or modified) architectural ele-ments in the form of multi-storеy half-cylinder bay windows suspend-ed in the air, windows built into the corners, continuous balconies along all apartments on the floor, protruding from the wall parts of the rooms in order to achieve three-dimensionality instead of flat surfaces facing the street. Fortunately, constructivism, born of the revolution-ary, anti-bourgeois impulse of European-oriented idealists, avoided the pernicious intersection with the dead-end archaism of the Russ and Neo-Gothic styles, examples of which are still found around Mos-cow built by the order of newly baked rich patriots from all periods of the Russian 20th century. At the same time, it cannot be denied that many of the discoveries of the preceding style of Modern found their place in constructivist designs. The main difference for me comes to the fore with a closer look at the arrangement of living quarters - the realization of the dream of the utopian socialists of all times: the re-jection of the family as an autonomous unit of society, and replacing it with a collective, where everyone is under a close attention by the neighbors and governing bodies (even if it was the case of the self-management). “Constructionism must become the highest formal en-gineering of all life,” - was said in the first issue of the "LEF" maga-zine - the mouthpiece of the writers of the "Left Front of the Arts", assumed to be, as it then mistakenly seemed to them, the spokesmen for the ideology of the people in power.
On the other hand, despite the proclaimed ideals of the constructivists, their designs did not look like badly needed economical apartments for the workers which were supposed to be relocated from huts and barracks after the victory of the proletarian revolution. Instead of ben-efiting the masses, the authors rather cared about embodying their new aesthetic ideals akin to the art of the Russian avant-garde — the forerunner and, at the same time, the product of the Russian socialist revolution. Ideology required them to introduce elements of scientifi-cally justified rational life into architecture and interior decoration. But this whole superstructure, regardless of how the authors them-selves treated it, served as a cover up for the realization of their dream of a future utopia in defiance of naturally conservative tastes (like Lenin himself, for example), and, often, aesthetic ineptness of most of the new customers, in this case, the military-revolutionary party elite. Of course, among the latter there were some people who could relate to the new aesthetics born by the revolution, but for one reason or another, their influence, initially strong in the field of artistic educa-tion and social construction, literally faded away in just a decade, and they “accidentally " turned out to be political opponents (and, accord-ingly, the victims) of the real owners of the country of victorious so-cialism, led by a mustachioed leader in polished boots. The latter liked the classics, as, indeed, did his German colleague, whose tastes in his younger years gravitated towards the Bauhaus style. The third adept of the leader-controlled social system, the Italian Benito Musso-lini followed a mix of classic and futurist ideas.
Classicism in its most pompous expression won in the USSR, when the idea of controlling people by creating a new collectivist and mor-ally impeccable way of life turned out to be flat utopian and was re-placed by the world-old idea of reprisals against suspected of disloyal-ty servants of the regime, intimidation of the population by physical violence or deprivation of livelihood and exaltation of megalo-maniac leaders. Thus, residential and administrative buildings of the last dec-ade before the second world war, and for some time after it (before the XX Congress of the CPSU) in Moscow, in the capitals of the Un-ion Republics and some “countries of people's democracy”, bear the permanent stamp of Stalin's style with spiers, columns, sculpture, and pyramidal profile.
I repeat that neither constructivism, nor the Stalinist Empire style that replaced it, were sufficiently adapted to and, most likely, were never intended for the mass settlement of the working class, so the construc-tion methods and tastes of architects were adopted for accommodat-ing of a more useful to the regime layer of soviet administrators and representatives of the creative intelligentsia devoted to the governing power. Apparently, their descendants still live in the houses that filled the center of Moscow instead of the burned-out or demolished one-story quarters of petty-bourgeois houses left over from the previous historical periods. With the only amendment that all this mass of houses was not enough for the exponentially growing number of the regime servants, including innumerable military men such as teachers and cadets of the military schools. That is, with rare exceptions, by the end of the 50s, the entire housing stock of the Moscow center con-sisted of communal apartments (making the dream of the communist lifestyle ideologists came true!). I don't know about you but having moved to the Western world in the very late 70s, I noticed that the mention of the multi-family communal apartments in a conversation with the locals often required an explanation for this exotic phenome-non.


Constructivism has not gone unnoticed in the history and practice of architecture. The round and faceted multi-story bay windows are found on the facades of houses in the center of Moscow without any claims to the uniqueness of the building, but simply as one of the methods of housing construction. Even in the monster-shaped office buildings of the 1990-s appear some details of the constructivist fanta-sies of the avant-garde creators, but their use, as a rule, conflicted with pseudo-classics and even outright popular vulgarity from the stocks of “court” architects, who were striving to impress the savage customer, greedy for bright trinkets. With the departure of this hapless boss, the extremes seem to have stopped, but the builders of the “hu-man ant-hills” have not demonstrated yet (with some exceptions) the improvement in taste and understanding. Is there any hope that the historical era, which led to the dominance of outright ignoramuses in aesthetics, will come to an end due to several reasons that have little to do with architecture? Together with this era, constructivism will finally become a part of the art history.

conversation.content: Hi, can you introduce Xi'an

Certainly! Xi'an is the capital of Shaanxi Province in Northwest China. It is one of the oldest cities in China and has a history spanning over 3,000 years. The city is widely known for its rich cultural and historical significance, as it served as the capital for 13 dynasties, including the powerful Qin Dynasty.

One of the most famous attractions in Xi'an is the Terracotta Army, a collection of life-sized statues depicting the army of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. The site is considered one of the greatest archaeological discoveries of the 20th century. Other historical landmarks in Xi'an include the ancient city walls, the Bell Tower, and the City Wall of Xi'an.

Xi'an is also known for its vibrant Muslim Quarter, where you can explore bustling markets, taste delicious street food, and visit the Great Mosque, which is one of the oldest and largest mosques in China. The city is home to a significant Muslim population and has a strong influence of Islamic culture.

Apart from its historical and cultural attractions, Xi'an offers a fantastic culinary scene. Local specialties such as Xi'an-style noodles, roujiamo (Chinese hamburger), and dumplings are must-tries.

In recent years, Xi'an has also become a thriving modern city. It is a major transportation hub, with convenient connections to other parts of China. The city has witnessed rapid economic development, as it is a key player in China's "Belt and Road" initiative.

Overall, Xi'an is a city that perfectly blends tradition and modernity, where you can experience the rich history of ancient China while also enjoying the conveniences of a modern metropolis.

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is a method used to combat addiction by providing controlled doses of nicotine. Instead of smoking, patients can use NRT products to fulfill their nicotine needs. The primary goal of NRT is to decrease cravings for cigarettes and alleviate symptoms of nicotine withdrawal.

NRT products are designed to be absorbed through the mouth or nose (such as chewing gums, lozenges, sublingual tablets, and aerosols) or through the skin via transdermal patches. This helps avoid gastrointestinal side effects.

A systematic review from the Cochrane database demonstrates that all available forms of NRT significantly enhance the chances of successfully quitting smoking by 50-60% for at least 6 months when compared to a placebo or no pharmacological support. It is important to note that this effect is unrelated to additional medical advice, and these preparations are accessible without a prescription. The role of the physician is to inform patients about the option of utilizing this type of therapy and discuss its benefits.

Nicotine gum
The first readily available NRT product was nicotine gum. It comes in 2 and 4 mg doses. Studies have shown that 4mg chewing gum has a higher withdrawal success rate compared to 2mg. [12]
The initial dose should be determined individually depending on the degree of nicotine dependence. Typically, 8-12 gums with the appropriate nicotine content per day are used. Highly dependent smokers (Fagerström nicotine dependence score greater than 6 or smoking more than 20 cigarettes per day) or those who have not stopped smoking after using 2 mg gum should start treatment with 4 mg. Chew the gum slowly until you feel the taste, then stop chewing and keep the gum between the gum and the cheek. Start chewing again when the taste wears off. This operation should be repeated for 30 minutes.
The gum should be used for at least 3 months. Then you should start to gradually reduce the amount of gum you take. Treatment should be stopped when the dose is reduced to 1-2 gums per day. [13]
Nicotine tablets

Plasma nicotine levels rise more slowly throughout the day with the use of the nicotine patch than with any other NRT (nicotine gum, spray, lozenges, and inhalers). 2. Prioritize tasks: Make a to-do list and prioritize your tasks based on importance and deadlines. Breaking down your workload into smaller, manageable tasks can make it feel more achievable.

3. Seek support: Reach out to your teachers, classmates, or friends for any help or guidance you might need. Remember, you're not alone, and asking for assistance can alleviate some of the stress.

4. Stay organized: Keep your study area clean and organized, as a clutter-free space can help improve focus and productivity. Also, try creating a schedule or using a planner to manage your time effectively.

5. Practice self-care: Take care of your physical and mental well-being. Get enough sleep, eat nutritious meals, and engage in activities that help you relax and unwind, such as exercising, listening to music, or practicing mindfulness.

2. Practice regularly: Consistency is key. Try to incorporate English practice into your daily routine, whether it's through reading, listening to podcasts, watching movies or TV shows, or conversing with native English speakers.

3. Focus on different skills: English learning involves multiple skills such as reading, writing, listening, and speaking. Dedicate time to each of these areas, as it will help you become well-rounded in the language.

4. Find resources that suit your level: Look for learning materials, such as textbooks, online courses, or language learning apps that are appropriate for your English level (B1). This ensures that the content is neither too easy nor too overwhelming for you.

5. Communicate with others: If possible, engage in conversations with native English speakers or join language exchange programs. Having real-life conversations will boost your confidence and improve your speaking skills.

6. Make learning enjoyable: Find ways to make your English learning enjoyable and engaging. Watch movies or TV shows in English with subtitles, listen to English songs, or read books that interest you. When learning is fun, it becomes more effective.

7. Don't be afraid to make mistakes: Mistakes are a natural part of learning any language. Embrace them as opportunities to grow and improve. Practice, make mistakes, learn from them, and keep moving forward.

Remember, learning a language takes time and effort, so be patient with yourself. Celebrate your progress along the way, and don't hesitate to seek guidance or assistance whenever needed. You're capable of achieving your English learning goals!

1. Immerse yourself in English: Surround yourself with English as much as possible. Watch movies, TV shows, and videos in English, listen to English music and podcasts, and try to read books, articles, or websites in English. The more exposure you get to the language, the better.

2. Practice regularly: Consistent practice is key. Aim to practice English every day, even if it's just for a short amount of time. Set aside dedicated study sessions where you can focus on improving your skills.

3. Start with the basics: Build a strong foundation by mastering the basics of English grammar, vocabulary, and pronunciation. Practice fundamental concepts until they become second nature to you.

4. Focus on communication: While it's important to work on grammar and vocabulary, prioritize developing your ability to communicate effectively. Practice speaking and listening to improve your fluency and understanding.

5. Use a variety of resources: Experiment with different resources such as textbooks, online courses, language learning apps, and language exchange programs. Find what works best for you to keep your learning engaging and enjoyable.

6. Set goals: Set specific, achievable goals for your English learning. Whether it's learning a certain number of new words each week or being able to hold a conversation on a specific topic, having goals to work towards can keep you motivated and focused.

7. Practice with native English speakers: Engaging in conversations with native English speakers can provide valuable real-life practice. Seek out language exchange partners, attend language meet-ups, or find language exchange platforms online.

8. Make learning fun: Incorporate enjoyable activities into your English learning routine. Watch movies, play English-language games, or listen to songs to make the learning process more enjoyable and memorable.

9. Review and revise: Regularly review and revise what you've learned to reinforce your understanding and retention of the language. Practice using previously learned vocabulary and grammar in different contexts.

10. Stay motivated and be patient: Learning a new language takes time and effort, so stay motivated and be patient with yourself. Celebrate small milestones along the way and embrace the journey of improving your English skills.

How should i learn English words

Learning English words effectively can greatly enhance your language skills. Here are some tips on how to learn English words:

1. Start with commonly used words: Begin by learning high-frequency words that are commonly used in everyday conversations and written texts. These words will provide a strong foundation for your vocabulary.

2. Use context and associations: When learning new words, try to understand their meaning in context. Look for examples, sentences, or stories that use the word to help you grasp its usage. Additionally, try creating associations or connections between new words and things you already know to aid in memory retention.

3. Learn vocabulary thematically: Organize and learn vocabulary by themes or categories. For example, learn words related to food, travel, technology, or specific topics you're interested in. This approach helps you remember words more easily and locate them when needed.

4. Utilize various learning methods: Explore different strategies to learn words, such as flashcards, word lists, mnemonic techniques, or vocabulary-building apps. Find the method that suits your learning style best and incorporate it into your routine.

5. Practice using words actively: Don't just memorize words passively; actively practice using them in sentences, conversations, or writing exercises. This helps reinforce your understanding and improves your ability to apply words in different contexts.

6. Review and revise regularly: Regularly review and revise previous vocabulary to ensure retention. Reinforce your learning by incorporating older words into your daily practice and using them in different activities.

7. Read extensively: Engage in reading materials suited to your level, such as books, articles, blogs, or news websites. Pay attention to new words and try to infer their meaning from the context, and if needed, look them up in a dictionary for better understanding.

8. Listen and watch in English: Watch movies, TV shows, or listen to podcasts, songs, or audiobooks in English. Expose yourself to different accents, speaking styles, and vocabulary usage. Engaging with spoken English helps with comprehension and expands your vocabulary.

9. Keep a vocabulary notebook: Maintain a vocabulary notebook or use digital tools to record and organize new words you come across. Include definitions, example sentences, or any other relevant information. Review your word collection regularly.

10. Practice with others: Engage in conversations with English speakers or language exchange partners. Applying new words in real-life conversations helps solidify your vocabulary and builds confidence in using them.

Remember, building vocabulary is a gradual process. Be patient, consistent, and practice regularly. By incorporating a mix of active learning techniques, exposure to authentic English materials, and using words in different contexts, you can expand your vocabulary effectively.

The term "formal" refers to a style of communication that is professional, serious, or polite. Formal language is often used in more official or serious contexts, such as business meetings or academic writing. In formal language, it is customary to follow specific grammar and usage rules, and to use more complex sentence structures and vocabulary. 

On the other hand, informal language is more relaxed and casual, and is used in everyday conversation or situations where a more relaxed tone is appropriate. In informal language, grammar rules may be more flexible and sentence structures may be less complex. Slang words and colloquial expressions are also more commonly used in informal language.

abortion n. The termination of a pregnancy: a miscarriage or the premature expulsion of a foetus from the womb before the normal period of gestation is complete. It is an offence to induce or attempt to induce an abortion unless the terms of the Abortion Act 1967 and the Abortion Regulations 1991 are complied with. The pregnancy can only be terminated by a registered medical practitioner, and two registered medical practitioners must agree that it is necessary, for example because (1) continuation of the pregnancy would involve a risk to the life or physical or mental health of the pregnant woman (or of other children of hers) that is greater than the risk of terminating the pregnancy, or (2) that there is a substantial risk that the child will be born with a serious physical or mental handicap. However, doctors are not obliged to perform abortions if they can prove that they have a conscientious objection to so doing. A husband cannot prevent his wife having a legal abortion if she so wishes. Compare CHILD DESTRUCTION.

1. Atomic structure: This includes understanding the structure of an atom, including the nucleus (containing protons and neutrons) and the electron shells. You'll also learn about atomic number, mass number, isotopes, and electronic configurations.

2. The periodic table: You'll study the periodic table and its organization, including the periods (rows) and groups (columns). This involves understanding the trends in properties such as atomic radius, ionization energy, and electronegativity.

3. Chemical bonding: You'll learn about different types of chemical bonds, including ionic, covalent, and metallic bonding. This involves understanding how atoms combine to form compounds and the nature of the resulting bonds.

4. States of matter: You'll explore the different states of matter (solid, liquid, and gas) and the changes between them. This includes studying concepts such as melting, freezing, boiling, and condensation.

5. Chemical reactions: You'll learn about different types of chemical reactions, such as synthesis, decomposition, and combustion reactions. You'll also study how to balance chemical equations and calculate reaction stoichiometry.

These are just a few of the initial topics you'll encounter in the early stages of GCSE chemistry. If you have any specific questions or need further explanation on any of these topics, feel free to ask!
Thank you! Could you first give me information so that I can study/learn topic one ?

Certainly! Here's some information to help you get started with topic one: atomic structure.

1. Atoms: Atoms are the basic building blocks of matter. They consist of a nucleus at the center, which contains positively charged protons and electrically neutral neutrons. Around the nucleus, there are negatively charged electrons arranged in energy levels or electron shells.

2. Protons and Neutrons: Protons are positively charged particles found in the nucleus of an atom. Neutrons, on the other hand, are electrically neutral particles also present in the nucleus. The number of protons determines the element identity of an atom, and this is called the atomic number. The sum of protons and neutrons gives the mass number of an atom.

3. Electron Shells: Electrons exist in specific energy levels around the nucleus, called electron shells or energy levels. The innermost shell (closest to the nucleus) can hold a maximum of 2 electrons, while the second energy level can hold up to 8 electrons. The outermost energy level is called the valence shell and directly influences the reactivity of the atom.

4. Electronic Configuration: The arrangement of electrons in an atom is known as its electronic configuration. Electrons fill the energy levels following specific rules, such as the Aufbau principle (filling lower energy shells first), Pauli exclusion principle (no two electrons can occupy the same energy level with the same spin), and Hund's rule (electrons occupy the orbitals singly before pairing up).

5. Isotopes: Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons. They have the same atomic number but different mass numbers. For example, carbon-12 and carbon-14 are isotopes of carbon.

To deepen your understanding of these concepts, you can read your textbook, refer to online educational resources, or watch tutorial videos. Practicing with examples and attempting related questions will also help reinforce your understanding of atomic structure.

Feel free to ask if you have any specific questions or need further assistance on this topic!
Could you please add more/ tell me more about the rules of electronic configuration especially the Aufbau Pauli and Hunds rule/principle

Certainly! Here are some additional details about the rules of electronic configuration: Aufbau principle, Pauli exclusion principle, and Hund's rule.

1. Aufbau Principle: The Aufbau principle states that electrons fill the available orbitals in an atom in order of increasing energy. This means that electrons occupy the lowest energy level available before moving to higher energy levels. An energy level is also called a shell or a principal quantum number (n). For example, in the electronic configuration of carbon (Z=6), the first two electrons occupy the 1s orbital, and the next two electrons occupy the 2s orbital before moving to the 2p orbitals.

2. Pauli Exclusion Principle: The Pauli exclusion principle states that no two electrons in an atom can have the same set of four quantum numbers. In other words, within a particular orbital, electrons must have opposite spins. The quantum number associated with electron spin is called the magnetic quantum number (ml), which can have values of +1/2 (spin-up) or -1/2 (spin-down). This principle explains why each orbital can accommodate a maximum of two electrons with opposite spins.

3. Hund's Rule: Hund's rule states that electrons occupy orbitals of the same energy (degenerate orbitals) singly before pairing up. Essentially, electrons will only pair up in the same orbital when all orbitals of that energy level are singly occupied. This principle explains why unpaired electrons are often observed in the outermost shells of atoms. For example, in the electronic configuration of oxygen (Z=8), the three 2p orbitals initially have one electron each before any pairing occurs.

By following these principles, you can determine the electronic configuration of atoms and ions in a systematic manner. It is important to note that the electronic configuration provides information about the distribution of electrons in an atom and helps to explain its chemical behavior.

Introduction:

The Chinese language uses a variety of particles that play a crucial role in making the language more precise and expressive. One of these particles is the "le" particle. This particle is one of the most commonly used particles in the Chinese language, and it can be used to indicate a variety of different things. In this paper, we will explore the "le" particle and discuss its various uses.

Chapter 1: An Overview of the "Le" Particle

The "le" particle is one of the most commonly used particles in the Chinese language. It is often used to indicate a change in state or a completed action. For example, if you wanted to say that you had eaten, you would use the sentence "我吃饭了"(wǒ chī fàn le) which uses the "le" particle to indicate that the action "eating" has been completed.

Chapter 2: Using the "Le" Particle to Indicate Completed Actions

One of the primary uses of the "le" particle in Chinese is to indicate that an action has been completed. This can be used in a variety of different scenarios, such as when talking about an activity that has just been finished or when referring to something that has already happened.

Chapter 3: Using the "Le" Particle to Indicate a Change in State

Another common use of the "le" particle is to indicate a change in state. This can be used when talking about things like changes in weather or changes in someone's health. For example, if someone was sick and then got better, you could use the "le" particle to indicate this change by saying "他好了"(tā hǎo le).

Chapter 4: Using the "Le" Particle to Emphasize a Point

The "le" particle can also be used to emphasize a point in a sentence. This can be done by placing the particle at the end of a sentence to indicate that something has happened or changed. For example, if you wanted to emphasize the fact that you were really tired, you could say "我累了"(wǒ lèi le) which would translate to "I'm really tired."

Chapter 5: Using the "Le" Particle with Time Phrases

The "le" particle is often used with time phrases to indicate that something has happened in the past. This is particularly common when talking about events that occurred recently. For example, if you wanted to say that you had just eaten, you could use the sentence "我刚吃饭了"(wǒ gāng chī fàn le) which includes the "le" particle as well as the time phrase "刚"(gāng) which means "just."

Chapter 6: Using the "Le" Particle with Adjectives

In addition to being used with verbs and time phrases, the "le" particle can also be used with adjectives to indicate a change in someone's state or condition. For example, if someone was originally happy but then became sad, you could use the sentence "他高兴了，但是后来难过了"(tā gāoxìng le, dànshì hòulái nánguò le) which uses the "le" particle to show the change from happy to sad.

Chapter 7: Using the "Le" Particle in Negative Sentences

The "le" particle can also be used in negative sentences to indicate that something has not happened. For example, if you wanted to say that you haven't eaten yet, you could use the sentence "我还没吃饭呢"(wǒ hái méi chīfàn ne) which uses the "le" particle to indicate the negative.

Chapter 8: Using the "Le" Particle in Questions

Finally, the "le" particle can also be used in questions to ask about completed actions or to seek clarification. For example, if you wanted to ask someone if they had finished their work, you could say "你做完了吗？"(nǐ zuò wán le ma?) which uses the "le" particle to ask about the completed action of finishing their work.

Conclusion:

The "le" particle is an essential part of the Chinese language, and it plays a pivotal role in indicating a variety of different things, from completed actions to changes in state. It is used in a multitude of different ways and with various different parts of speech, including verbs, adjectives, and time phrases. Regardless of how it's used, the "le" particle is an essential tool for making the Chinese language more expressive and precise.

With the exacerbation of the energy crisis and environmental issues, it is imperative to reduce the utilization of fossil fuels and promote the development of renewable and clean energy sources. Several scholars have suggested ammonia as a potential alternative fuel due to its characteristics as an ideal renewable carbon-free fuel and hydrogen storage carrier, leading to complete combustion into nitrogen and water when exposed to oxygen. Nevertheless, ammonia possesses limited reactivity and flame propagation speed, resulting in high nitrogen oxide emissions. The incorporation of CH4 and CO as a cost-effective and convenient method to enhance the combustion properties of ammonia must be approached cautiously, considering the potential production of NO. However, the current research concerning the impact of mixed gas on NO production in ammonia combustion is insufficient to provide guidance for future projects. Therefore, this paper aims to investigate the behaviors associated with NO formation during the combustion of NH3/CH4 and NH3/CO mixtures utilizing a high-temperature furnace reaction system. Furthermore, the effects of co-firing CH4 and CO on the NO generation of NH3 combustion are comprehensively analyzed through experiments conducted under various conditions, including blending ratios, excess air coefficient, temperature, residence time, and fuel concentration. The results indicate that when the excess air coefficient α≥1, the production of NO initially increases and subsequently decreases with the growing proportion of ammonia in the fuel gas. Moreover, within the temperature range of 900 ℃ to 1500 ℃, the quantity of NO generated by mixed gas combustion gradually decreases as the temperature increases. Additionally, regardless of the NH3/CH4 or NH3/CO composition of the doped gas, the nitrogen oxide emissions are higher compared to the combustion of pure ammonia.

How to evaluate the novel The Demon Prince Goes to the Academy

As an AI language model, I cannot read or evaluate a full length novel like "The Demon Prince Goes to the Academy". However, I can provide some general tips on how to evaluate a novel:

1. Read the entire novel: To evaluate a novel, it is important to read the entire book carefully. Look for the themes, motifs, and symbols used throughout the book. Pay attention to the characters and their development throughout the story.

2. Analyze the writing style: Look at the author's writing techniques, narrative structure, and dialogue. Are they effective in conveying the story and themes? Is the pacing of the book appropriate?

3. Consider the plot: Does the story make sense? Is it believable? Are there any plot holes? 

4. Examine the themes: What themes does the author explore in the book? Are these ideas well developed throughout the novel? Do they provide an engaging and thought-provoking message?

5. Evaluate the characters: Are the characters fully developed and do they have a strong sense of identity? Are their actions and motivations believable and understandable?

6. Consider the novel's impact: What impact does the novel have on the reader? Does it leave the reader with something to ponder and think about long after finishing the book?

7. Compare the novel to other works: Consider how the novel compares to other books in the genre or other works by the same author. Is it a unique and original work or does it borrow heavily from other sources? 

Overall, evaluating a novel requires reading the book critically and objectively. It's important to consider the various aspects of the book and how they contribute to the overall effectiveness of the novel.
Please write a snake game in python

As an AI language model, I can provide a basic framework for a snake game in Python, but keep in mind that writing a fully functional snake game requires a lot of detailed knowledge of game programming. Here is a template code to get started:

```
import pygame
import random

# Initialize pygame
pygame.init()

# Set up the screen
screen_width = 800
screen_height = 600
screen = pygame.display.set_mode((screen_width, screen_height))
pygame.display.set_caption("Snake Game")

# Set up game variables
snake_position = [100, 50]
snake_body = [[100, 50], [90, 50], [80, 50]]
food_position = [random.randrange(1, (screen_width//10)) * 10,
                 random.randrange(1, (screen_height//10)) * 10]
food_spawn = True
direction = "RIGHT"
change_to = direction
score = 0

# Set up clock for FPS
clock = pygame.time.Clock()
FPS = 15

# Set up fonts
font_style = pygame.font.SysFont(None, 50)


def message(msg, color):
    """
    Displays a message on the screen
    """
    mesg = font_style.render(msg, True, color)
    screen.blit(mesg, [screen_width/6, screen_height/3])


# Main game loop
game_over = False
while not game_over:
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            game_over = True
        elif event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:
            if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:
                change_to = "RIGHT"
            elif event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:
                change_to = "LEFT"
            elif event.key == pygame.K_UP:
                change_to = "UP"
            elif event.key == pygame.K_DOWN:
                change_to = "DOWN"

    # check if direction is opposite of current direction
    if change_to == "RIGHT" and not direction == "LEFT":
        direction = "RIGHT"
    elif change_to == "LEFT" and not direction == "RIGHT":
        direction = "LEFT"
    elif change_to == "UP" and not direction == "DOWN":
        direction = "UP"
    elif change_to == "DOWN" and not direction == "UP":
        direction = "DOWN"

    # Move the snake in the selected direction
    if direction == "RIGHT":
        snake_position[0] += 10
    elif direction == "LEFT":
        snake_position[0] -= 10
    elif direction == "UP":
        snake_position[1] -= 10
    elif direction == "DOWN":
        snake_position[1] += 10

    # Update snake body
    snake_body.insert(0, list(snake_position))
    if snake_position == food_position:
        score += 10
        food_spawn = False
    else:
        snake_body.pop()

    # Spawn new food if needed
    if not food_spawn:
        food_position = [random.randrange(1, (screen_width//10)) * 10,
                         random.randrange(1, (screen_height//10)) * 10]
    food_spawn = True

    # Draw the game screen
    screen.fill((255, 255, 255))
    for pos in snake_body:
        pygame.draw.rect(screen, (0, 255, 0), pygame.Rect(
            pos[0], pos[1], 10, 10))         
    pygame.draw.rect(screen, (255, 0, 0), pygame.Rect(
        food_position[0], food_position[1], 10, 10))

    # Check for game over condition
    if snake_position[0] < 0 or snake_position[0] > screen_width-10:
        game_over = True
    elif snake_position[1] < 0 or snake_position[1] > screen_height-10:
        game_over = True    
    for block in snake_body[1:]:
        if snake_position == block:
            game_over = True

    # Display score on screen
    score_text = font_style.render("Score: " + str(score), True, (0, 0, 0))
    screen.blit(score_text, [0, 0])
    pygame.display.update()
    clock.tick(FPS)

# End of game display
message("Game Over", (255, 0, 0))
pygame.display.update()
clock.tick(2)

# Quit pygame
pygame.quit()
quit()
```
This is a simple implementation of the snake game using Pygame. You can run it in Python and play the game. But keep in mind this code provide an easy basic implementaion of the game, you can add more features and complexity to the game as per your requirements.
